Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Understanding and Facilitating Remote Triage and Rehabilitation During Pandemics via Visual Based Patient Physiologic Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This RAPID project plans to investigate visual-based physiological sensing technologies to facilitate remote triage and rehabilitation during pandemics, by using low-cost consumer-grade cameras to track such physiological conditions as respiration rate, heart rate, and blood oxygen saturation levels from videos. The physiological data can be visualized and archived, and shared by users with medical practitioners to understand and support remote triage and rehabilitation.<br/><br/>The proposed research can enhance the interaction between medical providers and patients, and help address a projected surge in telehealth needs due to COVID-19. The PI team plans to conduct the first-of-a-kind data collection, by incorporating the novel contact-free video sensing into a biomedical cohort study that is being rolled out by a public-health collaboration team. This cross-disciplinary opportunity of multimodal data collection will offer insights on the relationship of multiple biosensing modalities, and the data collected would facilitate the research on early detection of COVID-19 and related diseases. The visual-based physiological sensing will also help enhance the remote interaction between rehabilitation therapists and patients during pandemics.<br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this effort lies in advancing promising engineering techniques of video-based contact-free physiological monitoring to support the rising needs of remote triage and rehabilitation during pandemics. The research findings and techniques developed address an important missing component in telehealth, which simultaneously achieves social-distancing, avoids hospital overcrowding, and prioritizes personal protective equipment in response to pandemics. By collaborating with another cohort study, an unprecedented multitude of data collected by the joint effort will provide key insights toward understanding and managing COVID-19 diseases and remote triage for future outbreaks. The timeliness of this opportunity cannot be met by any regular NSF programs other than the RAPID.<br/><br/>The project’s broader impact lies in two aspects. The multidisciplinary effort will provide important new knowledge and insights toward understanding and developing technology capabilities for remote triage and rehabilitation, which will contribute to the early detection, spread control, and effective management and prevention of future epidemics. The techniques developed through the project to support tele-rehabilitation will have a strong potential to improve the adverse conditions and quality of life of the affected citizens.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to investigate visual-based physiological sensing technologies to facilitate remote triage and rehabilitation, by using low-cost consumer-grade cameras to track such physiological conditions as heart rate, blood oxygen saturation, breathing, and more from videos.  The physiological data can be visualized and archived, and shared by users with medical practitioners to understand and support remote triage and rehabilitation.

Under the support of NSF, we have carried out research activities aiming at advancing the understanding and methods on video-based physiological sensing. Recognizing that heartbeat signal plays a critical role in many physiological sensing tasks (such as breathing and blood oxygen estimation), we have investigated robust analysis and denoising of heart rate and heartbeat signal from videos.  Motivated by the clinical significance of monitoring blood oxygen levels from the early stages of the COVID pandemic, we have investigated contact-free privacy-respected sensing of blood oxygen using hand video. Compared to face video, the use of hand video enables easy compliance with social distancing and mask-wearing during the pandemic and protects the privacy of the person involved.  We have explored two types of approaches for measuring blood oxygen saturation from hand videos, namely, a principled approach by modeling the signal analytics pipeline and developing techniques grounded in signal processing and data science; and a primarily data-driven approach employing neural networks.  

Meanwhile, we have made a parallel effort to address the privacy sensitivity of facial video in physiological sensing, since both a person’s identity and his/her general health conditions are revealed at the same time.  We have developed an anonymization transform that removes sensitive visual information identifying an individual, while the meantime, preserving the subtle color and movement changes that contain relevant physiological information. This can help both address the privacy concerns and provide technical support to the technical community’s collaborations and benchmarking to advance this emerging area.  Such proactive effort can contribute to promoting as balanced performances of the technology as possible for different racial, ethnic, or gender groups.

We have also made significant progress toward transferring cutting-edge research into education and outreach.  The research outcome on video-based contact-free physiological sensing and the related physiological forensic aspects formed a primary basis for two tutorials that our PI team has given at leading international conferences on computer vision and information forensics.  We also showcased the new capabilities and high-level approaches achieved by this project in lecture material at the corresponding appropriate level at the freshman level, undergraduate senior level, and graduate level as well as in talks and seminars for broader audiences to raise the public’s awareness of the new technology advancement and nurture interests and appreciation among students.  

Overall, in terms of intellectual merit, the project has explored this emerging research area of video-based contact-free physiological sensing by drawing synergy across multiple disciplines including signal processing, computer vision, machine learning, biomedical engineering, medicine, and information security and privacy.  Through publications, talks, and related resources developed, our effort in this project contributed new algorithms, systematic understandings, and data collection and protection that the research community at large can learn and benefit from.  The broader impacts are two folds:  through engaging graduate and undergraduate students, the project’s integration of research with education and outreach has contributed to the preparation of the future generation of engineering workforce with interdisciplinary strength, and stimulated their interests to pursue engineering R&D careers. Meanwhile, through new technologies and tools developed, the research outcome of the project can benefit public health and achieve global and societal impact in a long run.
